Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2011 08:23PM angelsister wrote: As well as pulling muscles you can also cause inflammation of the pleura (pleurisy) . This can be heard as a pleural ' rub' by someone listening to your chest. It can be very painful to breath deeply or cough. Imo it feels different to a muscular pain. Its treated with nsaid's and can take few weeks to resolve. Hope you feel better soon x

Posts.Title: More mets twinsmom96 seaperch

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 07:00PM angelsister wrote: Hi. I am in the uk and i have 3 sisters. The eldest of us is 59 and lives in the states. She had dcis 7 years ago, lx and rads, ned since. Second eldest (56) is slso in states snd was dx with stage iv bc thru a bone marrow biopsy in jan 2008. There are two of us still in uk where were born. We all get yearly mammo's and i had lumpectomy 4 years ago but thankfully - b9! Second eldest sister is cyn who is stage iv. Since her diagnosis she has had countless blood and platelet transfusions as her bone mets are widespread and diffuse. Its always been her counts that have been the biggest problem. She has had xeloda, zometa, ac, , femara, aridea, neupogen, neulasta, gemzar and most recently intrathecal chemo ( dunno name) but she had dextramethazone infusion first. She also had an intravenous radiation treatment which was trult terrible in terms of delayed se's. Me and my sister in england have been with her for 8 months out of the last 3 years and hate not to be thete for her all the time. My sister who had dcis and lives in the states is not a 'coper' and isn't always there to support cyn. I have really appreciated this site, to hear about others who are facing this bloody disears and also to get info and support. Thanks x
Posts.Title: to all new stage 4 members apple apple

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 02:31PM angelsister wrote: I think about you often clarissa. Well done on the first treatment, hope the se's are kind to you've got all your meds ready and waiting if you need any. Very best wishes x i got married at the beach in nc a couple of years ago so my sis could come. She is in sc x
Posts.Title: to all new stage 4 members apple apple

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2011 01:14PM - edited Dec 21, 2011 01:17PM by angelsister Hi naniam, my sisters bone mets were described as widespread and diffuse. Only 2 hot spots on her hip for which she ever had rads. Her biggest problems have been her blood counts because those cells are made in the bone marrow. I dont know what your bone mets are like but hers were spread so that before she ever had any chemo they had to give her blood transfusions and platelets and fluid some times every week. As for beong hard to control? Not necessarily, cyn didn't have a progression for over two years. Hope you get your chemistry sorted out soonand start to feel stronger. Best of wishes x

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2012 11:42PM - edited Feb 17, 2012 12:14AM by angelsister Coolbreeze, there is a theory that scratching a prosthetic limb while looking in a mirror makes your brain think that the itch is being scratched, i wonder if it would work on your breast? The other thing to try is deep pressure and vibration or firm brushing across the area(even if it as at the edge of where you lost sensation) as these types of stimulation should 'short circuit' the itch type signals x

Posts.Title: to all new stage 4 members apple apple

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2011 04:21AM angelsister wrote: Hi naniam it must be so so distressing that you didn't have these symptoms before you started treatment. And it seems like bone pain is a se of every drug they throw at you. Every ones body responds differently to these drugs and i doubt its to do with age and certainly not about how tough you are. So many times it seemed my sister was getting worse on treatments and then as her body started to recover she would start to feel a bit better and her disease would have slowed or stablised. The only drug she refused was xeloda as she simply couldn't get out of bed when she took that. Yet others find it very doable. I can tell you that when she got pain meds and stomach meds sorted out to help with the se's she managed a lot better. She also had to stop a chemo called gemzar which is supposed to be gentle as her se's were unbearable. Hang in there naniam, and talk to your onc about the se's. Im hoping you get some relief soon. Peace and love x

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 05:31PM angelsister wrote: Thanks so much for your post Mark. I'm so sorry that you lost your Amy. And i so understand why you say 'we' when you talk about what she and you had to endure. There is truth in the idea that unless you go through it yourself that you don't understand. But i understznd that you were there with her, experienced fear and pain because of wgat was happening. Were there times that you would have done snything to take it off her just for a while if you could? I truly hope that you are zble to find peace and thonk about her with smiles and pride very soon. My cyn i think is at a similar stage. She stayed off her pain meds today so we could talk. She wants us to know that she doesn't feel well enough to do more. She has had very few side effects from the chemo via lumbar puncture. Her head feels better and she was full of chat afterwards maybe because of the steroids. I am so incredibly proud of her and know that things will get tougher but i hope i will be up to the task of staying strong for her. Thanks again for your message. My sincerest best wishes and kindest thoughts. Steph x
Posts.Title: lumbar puncture and brain mets angelsister luvmywife

Posts.Content: angelsister wrote: Hi i think of you now as friends. Certainly you have shared my pain, my joy and my fear, what else could i call you? I have shared with you that which i have until now kept to myself. I have read about those of you waiting for test results, and raced to my computer to hear your news. I have honestly and truly punched the air having read of your good news. I have shed tears and cried for you in your pain and your fear. My life will never be the same having come upon you. So yes. ..Hello friends, i'm sad to say that my news is not good. Im getting flight on the 28th as my darling sister is in hospital and astonishingly she is ok with it. They are tryong to get her pain under control, i guess to send her home. I decided i had to get over to her ( in the states) so that whatever she needs, i can help with. She is coming to the end of her journey and i wish i could post a picture of her, to share her beauty with you. I said a prayer for you all and i will continue to think nothing but good things for you, whether you are newly diagnosed and afraid, going through chemo and suffering shitty se's or dancing with ned after great scans. I may not be in a position to post after tomorrow as i hope to spend all my time by my darling sisters side but i will still think of you and i will still be wishing you all you wish youselves. My very best wishes and my most sincere thanks for you sisterhood. It is unlikely that you will ever know the extent of the impact that you have had. I will go to cyn fortified with not only information but with hope and with strength to meet what faces her in the next few weeks. If i am up to the task, it will be, in no small way, down to you xxxx Steph Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 12:41PM angelsister wrote: Hi just wanted to add that you all really should check and be very careful in choosing hospice provider. Hospice at home where i live implies nursing care. My recent experience in the states was more like an equipment provision. So that o2 was delivered, drugs by fed ex, equipment like commode etc. But...nursing input consisted of a weekly visit to sort out meds and an emergency contact as you are no longer to call 911 and the offer of care/ aide to help with hygiene twice a week. I was shocked to be told no we can't come and put up iv morphine for instance you have to be inpatient for that. Please just check what is available. Best wishes xx

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2011 12:08PM angelsister wrote: Yey! That really is good news... It worked that way for my sister as its ONLY chemo that has kept her going for the last 3 years plus. She was diagnosed with bc which presented as a systemic illness. She was tested for malaria (as she'dbeen working in india) and was under the care of a haematologist with hgb of 7 and platelets of 1000. (wbc were normal tho). She was finally sent for bone marrow biopsy as leukemia was suspected. She was sent to her onc who suspected mbc. They reviewed all the mammos and couldnt find a mass but 1 radiologist identified a tiny mark. They couldnt do a biopsy as her platelets were so low. A bone scan showed ' widespread and diffuse' bone mets, no 'hot spots' just what cyn called speckles. So...they started chemo, no surgery - nothing to cut. No rads - nothing to radiate. Her onc told her they would do 6 arimidex (i think) and blood and platelet transfusions until her platelets could stay at 45000 on their own and then they'd add xeloda. I'll never forget the look on her face after 5 cycles and her onc did a little tap dance waving her counts as the blasted platelets had gotten to 27000 with no transfusion. Cyn was able to work in her yard, go to the store, visit friends etc. She was gutted when they said they wanted to do 3 more and add thr xeloda but she felt better than she had in a long time so she persevered. Anyway, she's done 4 other types of chemo since and they are only successful for a limited time for her but the efficacy was always measured in lowered tumour markers, better blood counts, rediced pain and feeling Better. She has had her fair share of side effects but she does not regret the last three years which she has had because of chemo....as no other treatments were indicated. We did our best to get her to eat right but she's pretty stubborn! She did drink a lot of water tho.
